mentions.context: Given the nature of λProlog, this specification is both compact and explicit about the scope of bindings for schematic variables and eigenvariables.
Appendix A contains a λProlog [28,29] executable specification of a predicate that relates a bipolar formula to its various bipoles.
The termination of this λProlog specification is easily shown using the measure of sequents mentioned above.
The key novelties of the syntax of λProlog for this implementation are the following.
( imp ( atm ( path v w ))( atm ( path u w )))) , which encodes the formulas ∀u∀v∀w(adj u v ⊃ path v w ⊃ path u w) then λProlog will solve this goal formula by computing the following substitution.
We briefly describe a logic program that can compute bipole inference rules from bipolar formulas: this implementation uses the λProlog programming language [28,29].

Since this logic programming language is typed, the keyword kind is used to introduce a new primitive type, and the keyword type The following four sequent structures are encoded using the corresponding λProlog terms, all four of which are also considered to be primitive premises (using the specification for primitivep above).
